709031f.text:
Fifth Avenue south from 58th Street. In the foreground, from 58th to 57th Streets, is the Cornelius Vanderbilt mansion, in the style of a French Chdteau. It was demolished in 1927, and the
site is now occupied by the Bergdorf Goodmman store.
The first church spire on the west side is the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian; beyond it are those of St. Thomas's (Protestant-Episcopal), Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas (Dutch Reformed), and, dimly in the background, the Brick Presbyterian and the Marble Collegiate (Dutch Reformmed). These churches are still standing (1935); but St. Thomas's has been rebuilt after it was partially destroyed
by fire.
About 1890.
Brown Brothers.

713870f-a.text:
57th Street, north side, east from Fifth Avenue, taken from the Heckscher Building, Fifth Avenue at S.W. corner of 57th Street. The large white building in the centre is the new Fuller Building, at the N.E. corner of Madison Avenue. Beyond it, on the N.E. Corner of Park Avenue, is the Ritz Tower, an apartment house.
August 15, 1929.
L. Sperr.  P. 1

709028f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 57th Street, seen from the Heckscher Building on the S.W. corner of 57th Street. 1 East 57th Street, on the corner, and the small house adjoining it, have been demolished in November and are to be replaced by a 15-story building. On the S.S. corner of 58th Street the 32-story Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, is shown in the later stages of construction. The new Savoy Plaza Hotel occupies the block from 58th to 59th Streets, and the Sherry-Netherland the N.W. corner of 59th Street, on the sites respectively of the old Hotels Savoy and Netherland. Beyond, on the S.E. corner of olst Street, the George A. Fuller Company is erecting a tall apartment house on the site of the old Elbidge T.
Gerry mansion.
Early 1930.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.
Neg ~ 252

and behind it is Heckscher Tower.

718355f-a.text:
Central Park: A view southeastward across the Pond (southeastern corner of the Park) showing toweing structures that border the edge. These are on the east side of Fifth Avenue, south from East 6lst to 57th Streets. From left to right, they are, the Hotel Pierre, Ritn Tower (N.E. corner of Park Avenue and E. 57th Street), the Sherry Netherland, the Savoy-Plaaa,
and the Squibb Building.
About 1936.
0ift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

view.

709029f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 57th Street, showing 1 East 57th Street, the last remaining house of "Marble Row", built early in 1871 by Mrs. Mary Mason Jones, who inherited the block from her father, John Mason. The group of houses, known as Marble Row, were notable as representing practically the first break with the brownstone tradition in New York.

This house, the first of the group, was occupied by Mrs. Jones herself. Its last resident was Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs; and in 1918 the New York Trust Company bought and remodelled it. In November 1929 it will be demolished to make room for the new 15-story New York Trust Company Building.

June, 1925.
